transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: When it comes to climate change, you've heard of melting icecaps and rising sea levels, but just how high will the sea levels rise in 20, 30 or 100 years? Will it be enough to notice the difference? New research now says the oceans will swallow up more and more of our coastline, rising not just inches but feet according to two new reports released by the National Research Council and the U.S. Geological Survey. They discovered that sea levels are rising on both the east and the west coasts, and they're climbing at a faster and faster rate. Why the drastic revision? Joining me now to talk about it is Peter Howd. He's an oceanographer who works for Cherokee Nation Businesses and a contractor for the U.S. Geological Survey. He's here in our New York studios. Welcome to SCIENCE FRIDAY.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: Thank you very much, it's a pleasure to be here.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: We had predicted that it would - rise by inches. Now they're saying much more.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: Yeah, we're looking at changes on the order of feet, and as our science and observations advance, we're becoming more and more secure in that level of range, although there's still a great deal of slop on either side of that as to where it will actually end up.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: Now, you were a researcher on the east coast study, right?

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: That's right. Well, we found an area of accelerated sea level rise that stretches from about Cape Hatteras up to north of Boston, and that's using historical measurements that went up to about - or through 2009.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: So that includes North Carolina.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: It includes the northern part of North Carolina, not the southern part. It's important to them.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: Yes. It's important to them. And so how much higher did you actually calculate it?

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: Well, we looked at acceleration rates. So how fast is the rate of sea level rise changing and found that, you know, if we projected that out that by the - by about 2100, there could be an extra eight inches to a foot of sea level there, in that region, above what it does on a global basis.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: Were you surprised by this?

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: We were surprised. I think we're very surprised at how well defined that region was, and that there was this very sharp transition right around the Cape Hatteras area between acceleration to the north and no acceleration to the south.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: 1-800-989-8255 is our number, talking with Peter Howd, if you'd like to talk about the ocean rise. You're saying - repeat that point that you just made.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: Yeah. We measured the acceleration, so we're looking at not the absolute rate at which sea level is rising but how fast is it increasing, how fast is that rate increasing, so like a car getting on the freeway...

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: ...how it's speeding up. And the west coast study, on the other hand, looked at, you know, how fast is sea level going, and what does that imply about the future? So there was a - we were more historians, and they were prognosticators on the west coast.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: And let's talk about the mechanics, the physics of what goes on in nature to make the sea level rise.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: Yeah. It's a mess - Coriolis force, the dreaded C-word.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: I love the Coriolis force.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: Yeah, yeah. It...

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: That's why things spin, hurricanes and...

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: Yeah...

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: ...spin in one direction.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: ...why everything spins. And it has to do with the fact that the Earth is rotating. So it's a physics problem.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: So tell us, describe...

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: ...we're a physics show.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: OK. So...

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: Feel at home here.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: So, you know, the oceans, they aren't just sitting there. It's not just still water. There are currents. There are winds blowing over the top of them. And in case of the circulation in the Atlantic, the wind is blowing, piles water up in the middle because of something called Ekman transport. You can look that up on Wikipedia. And it makes a big pile - a hill of water in the middle of the Atlantic.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: Really?

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: It's about a meter high, something like that.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: Yeah

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: And water tries to flow downhill toward the east coast, and Coriolis force makes it go north, and that's the gulfstream.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: That's the gulfstream. We're talking with Peter Howd on SCIENCE FRIDAY from NPR. I'm Ira Flatow. And so that's right. There's a pile of water. The Coriolis force gives a little spin...

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: Yup.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: ...and that makes the water flow off the coast. That's wow.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: Yeah. So instead of flowing, you know, to the west or...

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: ...depending on where the gulfstream north. You add flows along the contours - it's just like the wind in the atmosphere. It flows along the pressure gradients...

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: ...instead of across.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: So what makes the rise now when that...

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: So the rise, yeah, you can do - it's what? 2:30 on a Friday, you have a half drunk cup of coffee on your desk, just move it away from the computer, give it a stir and what you'll see, if you stir strong enough, that you'll develop a depression in the middle of the coffee cup, and it will rise up on the sides.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: So there's a relationship between the velocity of the coffee and the slope that you can generate there. And although the physics are very different in the ocean, you'll establish the same relationship between a pressure gradient or that difference in height and speed of the current. So if the gulfstream slows down, the slope at a sea surface is going to decrease, and water will rise at the coastline.

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: And what is this due to?

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: The slowing of the current? Yeah, that's the big question right now. And there's a lot of debate about what will drive those kinds of changes in the climate. But it really comes back to the distribution of temperature in the atmosphere and...

transcript.speaker: Ira Flatow
transcript.text: Global warming?

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: Global warming, you know, is warming or changes in the, you know, there are two theories right now kind of competing, although it's probably some of the both. transcript.text: If the water gets - just gets warmer, though, doesn't it expand the volume of it?

transcript.text: Yeah. Water will also - changing the temperatures, water gets warmer. We all know it expands and rises sea levels. So there's three causes of sea level rise. transcript.text: Now, the gulfstream goes north, and doesn't it take a right turn as it gets out of Canada and...

transcript.text: How...

transcript.text: Will this rise that you're predicting be noticeable in 100 years? Will the change affect the weather then?

transcript.speaker: Peter Howd
transcript.text: You know, if the driving forces are, you know, according to some of the scenarios that are out there, yes; according to some of the others, no. And it remains to be seen what climate is actually going to do.

transcript.text: So we're doing a real-life experiment.

transcript.text: We are...
